sport_description: Archery is a precision sport that involves using a bow to propel arrows at a designated target. The fundamental objective is to shoot the arrows as close as possible to the center of the target face, which is typically marked with concentric scoring rings. In target archery, the most common competitive discipline, archers shoot a set number of arrows from a fixed distance at a stationary, circular target. Scoring is based on which ring the arrow penetrates, with the inner-most ring (the gold) yielding the highest point value, usually 10 points. If an arrow touches a line between two scoring zones, the higher score is awarded.
history_description: Archery has prehistoric roots, used globally for hunting and warfare. The sport’s competitive structure was significantly developed in medieval and early modern England. The Grand National Archery Society codified early competitive rules, establishing modern tournaments. Its popularity in the UK led to its inclusion in early modern sporting events. It was contested at the 1900 Olympic Games.
equipment: Bow, Arrows, Target, Armguard, Finger tab or release aid.

sport_description: Artistic Gymnastics is a dynamic Olympic sport that showcases athletes' exceptional strength, flexibility, agility, and grace. It involves performing precise, choreographed routines on various pieces of apparatus. Men compete in six events: Floor Exercise, Pommel Horse, Still Rings, Vault, Parallel Bars, and Horizontal Bar. Women compete in four events: Vault, Uneven Bars, Balance Beam, and Floor Exercise. Routines are scored based on the difficulty of the skills performed and the perfection of their execution and artistry.
history_description: The roots of gymnastics trace back to Ancient Greece, used for physical and military training. The term "Artistic Gymnastics" emerged in 19th-century Germany but the modern competitive form debuted in Athens. Competitions began to flourish in European athletic clubs during the 1800s. The sport was included in the program of the first modern Olympic Games in 1896. The women's program was later fully standardized by the 1950s.
equipment: Floor Mat, Vault Table, Uneven Bars (Women), Balance Beam (Women), Parallel Bars (Men), Horizontal Bar (Men), Pommel Horse (Men).

sport_description: Artistic Swimming, formerly known as Synchronized Swimming, is a unique aquatic sport that blends elements of swimming, dance, and gymnastics. Athletes perform precise, choreographed routines in the water, synchronized with music from underwater speakers. The routines require immense strength, flexibility, endurance, and exceptional breath control to execute figures and acrobatic lifts without touching the pool bottom. Competitions feature solo, duet, and team events, and routines are judged on both technical execution and artistic impression. It is a highly demanding sport that showcases grace and athleticism.
history_description: This sport evolved from life-saving techniques and "water ballet" popular in the late 19th century. Early competitions were recorded in Berlin and London, initially featuring men. Canadian and American pioneers significantly advanced the sport in the 1930s. The sport, then called Synchronized Swimming, gained Olympic status in 1984. FINA officially changed the name to Artistic Swimming in 2017.
equipment: Swimming Pool, Nose Clip, Speakers (underwater and above water), Swimsuit (themed/performance attire).

sport_description: Athletics, commonly known as Track and Field in North America, is a diverse collection of competitive sports based on fundamental human movements. It encompasses four primary categories: running, walking, jumping, and throwing events. Running events range from short, explosive sprints to middle-distance, long-distance, and challenging relays or hurdles. Field events test power and technique, including jumps like the high jump and long jump, and throws like the javelin and discus. As one of the oldest and most universal sports, Athletics forms the core of the Summer Olympic Games and the World Athletics Championships. The main objective is to achieve the fastest time, greatest distance, or highest height in each specific discipline.
history_description: Running, jumping, and throwing are among the oldest competitive sports, originating with the Ancient Olympic Games in Olympia, Greece. The stadion footrace was the original event in 776 BC. Modern rules were largely defined in Western Europe and North America in the 19th century. Athletics remains the cornerstone of the modern Olympic Games since 1896.
equipment: Track and Field surface, Starting Blocks, Measuring Tapes, Timekeeping system, Javelin, Discus, Shot Put, Hammer, Vaulting Pole, Hurdles.

sport_description: Badminton is a fast-paced racket sport played on an indoor court, divided by a net, either as singles or doubles. Players use lightweight rackets to strike a unique projectile called a shuttlecock, or "birdie," over the net. The objective is to score points by landing the shuttlecock within the opponent's court boundaries before they can successfully return it. Matches are typically played in a best-of-three games format, with each game usually played to 21 points. The sport demands exceptional fitness, including aerobic stamina, agility, power, and precise technical skill.
history_description: The modern version developed from a game called Poona, played by British military officers in India during the 19th century. It was popularized upon their return to England at the Duke of Beaufort’s Badminton House. The sport's first set of official modern rules was formalized in Bath in 1873. The International Badminton Federation was established in 1934.
equipment: Racket, Shuttlecock (or "birdie"), Net, Court.

sport_description: Baseball is a classic bat-and-ball sport played by two teams of nine players on a field with four bases set in a diamond shape. The objective is for the offensive team to score "runs" by having a batter hit a pitched ball and then successfully touch all four bases, starting at home plate. The defensive team, which includes a pitcher and fielders, attempts to get three opposing players "out" by catching batted balls, striking out the batter, or tagging base-runners. A game is typically divided into nine innings, with each team getting a turn to bat and field in each inning. The team that accumulates the most runs by the end of the final inning is declared the winner.
history_description: Baseball's origins are linked to English bat-and-ball games like rounders. The game was formalized in New York by Alexander Cartwright, who codified the modern "Knickerbocker Rules." The first recorded game under these rules was played in 1845. The sport spread rapidly, becoming America's "national pastime" by the late 19th century.
equipment: Bat, Ball, Gloves (fielder's and catcher's), Bases, Pitching Mound, Uniform/Cleats, Helmets.

sport_description: Basketball is a dynamic team sport played on a rectangular court between two teams of five players. The primary goal is to score points by shooting a ball through the opponent's elevated hoop, which is ten feet high. Players advance the ball by dribbling (bouncing it on the floor) or passing it to teammates. Baskets scored from inside the marked arc are typically worth two points, while shots from beyond the arc count for three points. The fast-paced game is divided into periods, and the team with the highest total score when time expires wins.
history_description: Basketball was invented in December 1891 in Springfield, Massachusetts, by Canadian physical education instructor James Naismith. He created the indoor sport to keep athletes active during the New England winter. The original game used peach baskets as hoops and a soccer ball. The game spread quickly through the YMCA network and made its Olympic debut in 1936.
equipment: Ball, Hoops/Baskets (with backboards), Court, Scoreboard, Timekeeping device.

sport_description: Beach volleyball is an exciting team sport played by two players per side on a sand court divided by a net. The main objective is to ground the ball on the opponent's side by hitting it over the net with hands or arms. Unlike indoor volleyball, the two players must cover the entire court, demanding exceptional agility and communication. Each team is permitted up to three touches to return the ball across the net, encouraging strategic use of the pass, set, and attack. Matches are typically played in a best-of-three set format, often utilizing the rally scoring system where a point is scored on every play.
history_description: The sport is generally believed to have originated on Waikiki Beach, Hawaii, around 1915. It gained significant popularity in Santa Monica, California, during the 1920s with the establishment of courts. The game quickly evolved into the two-person competitive format. It gained professional status in the 1980s and was officially added to the Olympics in 1996.
equipment: Ball (slightly larger and softer than indoor ball), Net, Sand Court, Boundary lines.

sport_description: Boxing is a combat sport and martial art featuring two opponents, generally of similar weight, fighting in a boxing ring. Contestants, wearing padded gloves, attempt to score points by landing forceful and effective punches on their adversary. A match is divided into a predetermined number of short intervals called rounds, supervised by a referee. A fighter can win by knockout (rendering the opponent unable to continue), disqualification, or by judges' decision based on accumulated points. This intense sport requires high levels of conditioning, strategy, and mental toughness.
history_description: Boxing has ancient roots globally, but the modern, codified sport emerged in the United Kingdom. The Marquess of Queensberry Rules (1867) formalized the use of gloves, three-minute rounds, and the 10-second count. This development defined the sport as we know it today. Modern boxing became an official Olympic event in 1904.
equipment: Gloves, Mouthguard, Hand Wraps, Headgear (for amateurs/training), Ring (with ropes), Corner bucket/stool.

sport_description: Canoe slalom is a thrilling whitewater sport where athletes race against the clock down a turbulent river course. The objective is to navigate a kayak (K1) or canoe (C1) through a series of hanging gates as quickly and cleanly as possible. Gates, colored green for downstream and red for upstream, must be negotiated in the correct direction and sequence. Time penalties—two seconds for touching a gate and a hefty fifty for missing one—are added to the paddler's total run time. The sport demands immense skill, precision, and physical strength to master the currents and secure the best possible final score.
history_description: Canoe slalom is a relatively modern sport, originating in Switzerland in 1933. The early races were conducted on flat water, mirroring ski slalom courses. The sport quickly moved to natural whitewater to increase the challenge. The International Canoe Federation (ICF) was established in 1946. It became a permanent Olympic sport in 1992.
equipment: Canoe or Kayak, Paddle, Helmet, Life Vest, Spray Skirt, Whitewater Course, Hanging Gates (poles).

sport_description: Road cycling is an endurance sport where competitors race on paved public roads using lightweight bicycles. Competitions fall into two main categories: mass start events, like the famous Tour de France, where all riders start together and race to the finish line. The second type is the time trial, where individual riders or teams race solo against the clock for the fastest time. A key tactic in mass-start racing is drafting (riding closely behind another) to save energy from wind resistance. Road racing demands exceptional physical fitness, strategic teamwork, and technical skill in all terrains, from flat sprints to grueling mountain climbs.
history_description: Modern road cycling originated in Western Europe, with the first organized races taking place in France in 1868. The sport quickly gained prominence in France, Italy, and Belgium. Iconic races such as the Tour de France (1903) were established in the early 20th century. Cycling has been featured at the modern Olympic Games since their inception in 1896.
equipment: Road Bicycle, Helmet, Cycling Shoes, Racing Kit/Jersey, Timing Chip.

sport_description: Diving is a compelling aquatic sport where athletes perform elaborate acrobatic routines after springing from a springboard (3m) or falling from a fixed platform (10m). Competitors execute dives belonging to six groups (forward, backward, reverse, inward, twisting, and armstand) in positions like tuck, pike, or straight. A panel of judges scores the dive's execution based on the approach, take-off, flight, and the minimal-splash entry into the water. This execution score is then multiplied by the dive's degree of difficulty to determine the final points. The sport demands immense strength, flexibility, aerial awareness, and precision to achieve the perfect vertical entry.
history_description: Competitive plunging began in Great Britain in the 1880s. Fancy diving, or acrobatic diving, was introduced to Britain by Swedish and German gymnasts. The first recorded Scottish Championships were held in 1889. Diving became an Olympic event in 1904, combining various plain and fancy dives.
equipment: Springboard (1m or 3m) or Platform (5m, 7.5m, 10m), Diving Pool.

sport_description: Fencing is a dynamic combat sport based on traditional swordsmanship, pitting two athletes against each other on a narrow strip called a piste. Competitors use one of three distinct weapons—the foil, épée, or sabre—each having its own target area and rules for scoring a touch. Points are registered electronically when the weapon makes contact with the opponent's valid target area. The sport demands a unique blend of athleticism, lightning-fast reflexes, complex tactical planning, and intense focus. Considered one of the original modern Olympic sports, fencing is often likened to a fast-paced physical game of chess.
history_description: Fencing evolved from ancient sword combat in various cultures. It developed into a structured sport in Italy and Germany during the 14th and 15th centuries. Italian and French masters greatly influenced the modern techniques and training weapons. The first formal competition was held in London in 1880. Fencing is one of the few sports to have appeared at every modern Olympics since 1896.
equipment: Epee/Foil/Sabre (weapon), Mask, Jacket, Plastron (underarm protector), Glove, Body Cord, Electric Scoring Apparatus.

sport_description: Football, or soccer, is the world's most popular team sport, played between two teams of eleven players aiming to score by getting a ball into the opposing goal. Players are restricted from using their hands or arms to move the ball, relying instead on their feet, head, and torso. The game is played across two 45-minute halves on a rectangular field called a pitch. The team with the most goals at the end of the match is declared the winner. Governed by the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), its pinnacle event is the quadrennial FIFA World Cup.
history_description: Ancestral games were played worldwide, but modern Association Football (soccer) was codified in England. The Football Association (FA) was founded in London in 1863, establishing rules that prohibited carrying the ball. This act separated Association Football from Rugby. It quickly became the world's most popular sport.
equipment: Ball (size 5 for adults), Goals (or "nets"), Pitch, Corner Flags, Shin Guards, Cleats (boots).

sport_description: Handball is a fast-paced team sport played on an indoor court where two teams of seven players—six court players and a goalkeeper—compete to score goals. Players primarily use their hands to pass, dribble, and throw the ball, but they are restricted to holding the ball for only three seconds or taking three steps without bouncing it. The primary objective is to throw the ball into the opponent's goal, which is protected by a six-meter zone only the defending goalkeeper can stand in. Matches consist of two 30-minute halves, and the physical nature of the game makes it a demanding sport that requires speed, strength, and agility.
history_description: The modern sport of handball was invented in Berlin, Germany, in 1917 by Max Heiser and Carl Schelenz. The original version was outdoor "field handball." Schelenz modified the rules in 1919, suitable for men's international play. The indoor version, now commonly played, became an Olympic sport in 1972.
equipment: Ball, Goals (nets), Court, Timekeeping device.

sport_description: Hockey is a diverse family of team sports where players use curved sticks to propel a ball or a disk, known as a puck, into the opponent's goal. The most prominent versions are Field Hockey, played with a ball on grass or turf, and Ice Hockey, played with a puck on an ice rink while wearing skates. In all variations, the core objective is to score more goals than the opposing team through skillful stick-handling, passing, and shooting. These fast-paced games require excellent physical conditioning, precision, and strategic teamwork. Hockey is a widely popular global sport, featured prominently in both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games.
history_description: The sport of field hockey has deep roots in England, but the modern Ice Hockey version developed in Canada. The first recorded organized indoor game was played in Montreal in 1875 using rules established by McGill University students. The sport rapidly expanded across North America. Ice Hockey moved to the Winter Olympics after being featured in the 1920 Summer Games.
equipment: Stick, Puck (for Ice Hockey) or Ball (for Field Hockey), Skates (Ice), Pads/Protective Gear (shin, shoulder, helmet, gloves), Goal (with netting).

sport_description: Judo, which translates to "the gentle way," is a modern Japanese martial art and Olympic combat sport founded by Jigoro Kano in 1882. The main objective is to throw an opponent cleanly onto their back for an immediate victory, known as an Ippon. If a clean throw is not achieved, competitors aim to score points by executing throws, or immobilizing and subduing their opponent on the ground with pins, joint locks, or chokeholds. The sport emphasizes using an opponent's momentum and force to one's own advantage, rooted in the principles of "maximum efficiency, minimum effort" and "mutual welfare and benefit." Practitioners, called judoka, wear a uniform called a judogi and follow a strong moral code centered on respect and honor.
history_description: Judo was created in Japan in 1882 by Jigoro Kano. He adapted the ancient martial art of Jujutsu, removing its most dangerous elements. Kano aimed to create a safer, educational, and competitive sport emphasizing maximum efficiency. He founded the Kodokan to teach the martial art and its underlying philosophy. Judo became an official Olympic sport in 1964.
equipment: Tatami (mat), Judogi (uniform or "gi"), Belts (indicating rank).

sport_description: Karate is a Japanese martial art that uses striking techniques, including powerful punches, kicks, knee, and elbow strikes, alongside defensive blocks. The term karate literally translates to "empty hand," emphasizing unarmed combat. The sport has two main competitive disciplines: Kumite, which is sparring between two opponents with controlled contact to score points, and Kata, which involves solo performances of pre-arranged movements against imaginary opponents. Training focuses not only on physical prowess but also on developing mental discipline, respect, and character. It is practiced globally and has been featured as an Olympic sport.
history_description: Karate originated on the island of Okinawa (now part of Japan), influenced by indigenous fighting systems and Chinese martial arts. It developed as a hand-to-hand fighting system during periods when weapons were banned. Master Gichin Funakoshi introduced the synthesized martial art to mainland Japan in 1916. The sport spread globally after World War II.
equipment: Tatami (mat), Karategi (uniform or "gi"), Protective gear (mouthguard, mitts, shin pads, chest protector).

sport_description: Marathon swimming is an open water discipline defined by long-distance events, with the competitive minimum often set at 10 kilometers. Athletes compete in natural environments like seas, lakes, and rivers, facing challenges from currents, tides, and water temperature. The Olympic event is a single 10km race, which requires immense physical endurance, mental fortitude, and tactical awareness. Swimmers perform a mass start and must navigate the course without touching their support vessel or receiving external aid like wetsuits, making it a true test of human limits. Historical feats, such as the English Channel crossing, established this sport as the ultimate challenge in long-distance swimming.
history_description: The concept gained global attention when Captain Matthew Webb (UK) successfully swam the English Channel in 1875. This feat established the standard for long-distance, open-water swimming. The sport was officially recognized by FINA at the 1991 World Championships. The 10km marathon distance made its debut at the Beijing 2008 Olympics.
equipment: Open Water Course (lake, river, sea), Buoys (to mark course), Wetsuit (optional/dependent on water temperature), Safety Boat/Kayaks, Timing Chip.

sport_description: Rhythmic Gymnastics is a visually stunning Olympic sport that blends the artistry of ballet and dance with the athleticism of gymnastics. Competitors, either individuals or groups, perform elaborate choreographed routines set to music. These routines involve the skillful manipulation of a single hand apparatus, such as a ribbon, hoop, ball, clubs, or rope. Judges award points based on a combination of difficulty (leaps, pivots, balances), execution (technical precision), and artistry (expression and music synchronization). The sport demands exceptional flexibility, strength, coordination, and grace from its athletes.
history_description: The sport evolved from 19th-century movements emphasizing artistic expression and music. Its modern, competitive form began in the Soviet Union (now Russia) during the 1940s. The first formal competition was held in Leningrad in 1939. It was recognized by the International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) in 1961. Rhythmic Gymnastics made its debut as an individual event at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics.
equipment: Floor Mat, Apparatus (Rope, Hoop, Ball, Clubs, Ribbon), Leotard.

sport_description: Rowing is a challenging endurance sport where athletes race narrow, long boats called shells on rivers or lakes. Competitors propel their boat forward using oars that are fixed to the vessel, sitting with their backs to the direction of travel. Races are divided into two main disciplines: sculling, where each rower uses two oars, and sweep rowing, where each uses one oar with both hands. The sport demands extreme power, aerobic fitness, rhythm, and teamwork to cover the standard 2,000-meter race distance as quickly as possible. The largest boats, the eights, are steered by a coxswain, who also directs the crew's strategy and rhythm.
history_description: While rowing was historically a vital transport method, its modern sporting form originated in England. The most famous early competition is the annual Boat Race between Oxford and Cambridge Universities, first held in 1829. Organized racing led to the establishment of clubs and uniform rules. Rowing was included in the first modern Olympic Games in 1896.
equipment: Shell (boat, e.g., single scull, eight), Oars, Rowlock, Sliding Seat.

sport_description: Sailing is a dynamic water sport where competitors race sailboats around a marked course using only the power of the wind. Success depends on a complex combination of skill, strategy, and knowledge of aerodynamics, currents, and weather patterns. Athletes must constantly adjust the sails and rudder to maximize boat speed, a process called trimming. Races, often organized in a series known as a regatta, involve technical maneuvers and tactical duels to outmaneuver opponents and secure the best position on the water. Competitive sailing ranges from small, single-person dinghies to large-crewed ocean-going yachts.
history_description: Organized competitive yacht racing began in the 17th century in the Netherlands and the UK. The defining international competition is the America's Cup, first held in 1851 off the coast of England. The sport was scheduled for the first modern Olympics but debuted in Paris in 1900.
equipment: Sailboat (various classes, e.g., Dinghy, Keelboat), Sails, Mast, Rudder, Lines/Ropes, Life jacket (safety).

sport_description: Shooting sport is a competitive activity that tests a participant's accuracy, precision, and speed using various types of ranged weapons, primarily firearms. It encompasses diverse disciplines, broadly categorized into rifle, pistol, and shotgun events, each with distinct rules and equipment. In rifle and pistol competitions, athletes fire at stationary bullseye targets from set distances, often requiring extreme stillness from the standing, kneeling, or prone positions. Conversely, shotgun events like Trap and Skeet involve shooting at moving clay targets launched into the air at high speeds. Success in this sport demands intense mental focus, breath control, and meticulous physical discipline to consistently hit the center mark.
history_description: Competitive shooting evolved from the military and hunting use of firearms. The earliest recorded shooting match took place in Bavaria, Germany, in 1477. The sport gained popularity in Europe during the 19th century with the formation of civilian shooting clubs. Shooting was included as one of the nine core sports at the first modern Olympics in 1896.
equipment: Firearm (Pistol, Rifle, Shotgun), Ammunition, Target, Safety Glasses, Hearing Protection, Shooting Jacket/Vest (for certain disciplines).

sport_description: Swimming is an individual or team racing sport that requires an athlete to propel their body through water using coordinated movements of all their limbs. Competitive events take place in pools (either $25\text{m}$ short course or $50\text{m}$ long course) or in open water. Races are categorized by four main strokes: freestyle, backstroke, breaststroke, and butterfly, as well as the individual medley which combines all four. Success relies on a combination of endurance, explosive power, and highly refined technique to minimize water resistance and maximize speed. It is one of the most popular sports at the Summer Olympic Games, drawing worldwide attention. You can learn more about the basic concepts of the sport by watching this video
history_description: Swimming has been practiced since prehistory but emerged as a competitive sport in England in the early 1800s. The National Swimming Society began holding regular competitions in London in 1837. The introduction of the faster "crawl" stroke by non-European competitors in 1844 revolutionized techniques. Competitive swimming has been a feature of the Olympic Games since 1896.
equipment: Swimming Pool (or open water), Swimsuit, Cap, Goggles, Starting Blocks (in pool), Lane Ropes.

sport_description: Table tennis, or Ping Pong, is a dynamic, fast-paced racket sport played on a flat rectangular table divided by a low net. Players, either singles or doubles, use small wooden rackets covered in rubber to hit a lightweight, hollow ball back and forth. The objective is to score points by hitting the ball so your opponent cannot legally return it. Play is characterized by the emphasis on spin and quick, precise reflexes, making it a challenging sport that demands excellent hand-eye coordination. It has been an official Olympic sport since $1988$ and is enjoyed worldwide as both a competitive and recreational pastime.
history_description: This sport began as an "after-dinner" parlour game in Victorian England during the 1880s. It was an indoor adaptation of Lawn Tennis for colder weather. The first patent for a table game set was registered in 1890. The International Table Tennis Federation (ITTF) was established in 1926. It gained official Olympic status at the Seoul Games in 1988.
equipment: Racket (or "paddle"), Ball (celluloid or plastic), Net (and support posts), Table.

sport_description: Taekwondo is a dynamic Korean martial art and a combat sport, translating to "the way of the foot and fist." It is highly distinctive for its spectacular and fast kicking techniques, particularly head-height and spinning kicks. Competitive Taekwondo, an Olympic sport since 2000, features full-contact sparring (Kyorugi) where points are awarded for accurate and powerful strikes to the opponent's torso and head. Beyond physical training, Taekwondo emphasizes mental discipline and adherence to tenets like courtesy, integrity, and perseverance. Practitioners wear a traditional white uniform called a dobok and different colored belts to signify their rank and progress.
history_description: Taekwondo is a synthesis of ancient Korean martial arts, like Taekkyon, and external influences. The name "Taekwondo" was officially adopted in Seoul in 1955 by various martial arts masters. The World Taekwondo Federation (WT) was founded in 1973. It became a full Olympic sport in 2000, showcasing its global popularity.
equipment: Dojang (mat/training area), Dobok (uniform), Hogu (chest protector), Head protector, Mouthguard, Groin guard.

sport_description: Trampoline Gymnastics is a high-flying, Olympic-level sport where athletes perform complex acrobatic routines while continuously bouncing on a trampoline. These routines consist of a series of ten consecutive elements, which combine various somersaults and twists executed in precise body shapes like tuck, pike, or straight. Judges score the performance based on four main criteria: execution, difficulty of the skills, time of flight (time spent in the air), and horizontal displacement (staying near the center of the mat). The sport requires exceptional spatial awareness, control, and power, with gymnasts often soaring over 8 meters high to complete their breathtaking maneuvers. Individual Trampoline and Synchronised Trampoline are the two disciplines featured in the Olympic Games.
history_description: The modern trampoline was invented in 1934 in Iowa by George Nissen, inspired by circus safety nets. Nissen initially used it for training gymnasts and divers. The device quickly spread from a training tool to a recreational activity. The first US National Championships were held in 1948. Trampoline became an official Olympic discipline at the 2000 Sydney Games.
equipment: Trampoline Frame and Bed, Safety Mats (around the frame).

sport_description: Triathlon is a demanding endurance multisport race that requires athletes to sequentially complete three disciplines: swimming, cycling, and running in one continuous effort. The race begins with a swim, typically in open water, followed by a bike ride, and finishes with a run to the finish line. The time spent changing gear between events, known as transitions, is also counted in the total race time, effectively making it a "fourth discipline." Distances vary greatly, from short Sprint races to the grueling Ironman which includes a full marathon run. This sport, which has been an Olympic event since 2000, tests a competitor's fitness, mental toughness, and efficient movement between the three distinct segments.
history_description: While three-sport races existed in France decades earlier, the modern continuous triathlon began in the United States. The first recorded event was held in San Diego, California, in 1974. The sport gained international fame with the Ironman Hawaii race (1978). The International Triathlon Union (ITU) was established in 1989. Triathlon made its Olympic debut at the Sydney 2000 Games.
equipment: Swimming: Wetsuit, Goggles. Cycling: Road Bicycle, Helmet. Running: Running Shoes. Also: Race Belt, Transition Area equipment.

sport_description: Water polo is a highly demanding competitive team sport played in a pool by two teams of seven players, striving to throw a buoyant ball into the opponent's net to score. Players must continuously tread water—often using the efficient "eggbeater kick"—and are not permitted to touch the bottom or sides of the pool. The game is physically intense, requiring immense endurance, strength, and swimming speed, with a mix of strategies similar to soccer and basketball. Only the goalkeeper is allowed to use two hands on the ball; field players must control and pass the ball with one hand. Governed by a shot clock and divided into four quarters, the match is a constant battle for possession and goal opportunities.
history_description: The game originated in the rivers and lakes of England and Scotland in the mid-19th century. Early rules, established in London in 1870, led to a game resembling "water rugby." Scotland later developed a modern, faster version in the 1880s. Water Polo was the first team sport included in the modern Olympic Games, debuting in 1900.
equipment: Pool, Ball, Goals, Caps (ear guards and numbers), Timekeeping device.

sport_description: Weightlifting, or Olympic weightlifting, is a competitive strength sport where athletes attempt to lift the heaviest possible weight overhead using a barbell. The competition consists of two highly technical, explosive movements: the snatch and the clean and jerk. In the snatch, the barbell is lifted from the floor to an overhead position in one continuous motion. The clean and jerk is a two-part lift, first bringing the bar to the shoulders (the clean) and then driving it overhead (the jerk). The athlete's final score is the combined total of their highest successful lift in both events, and they compete across various bodyweight categories. It is a cornerstone of the Summer Olympic Games, testing power, speed, flexibility, and technique as much as pure strength.
history_description: The act of lifting heavy objects as a test of strength dates back to ancient civilizations. Modern organized competition primarily developed in Europe, notably Germany, during the 18th and 19th centuries. Weightlifting was included in the very first modern Olympic Games in Athens in 1896. The International Weightlifting Federation (IWF) was established in 1905.
equipment: Barbell, Weight Plates (discs), Collars (clips), Weightlifting Belt (optional), Platform.

sport_description: Wrestling is an ancient and globally practiced combat sport that involves grappling with an opponent to gain control. The objective is either to outscore the rival by executing throws and takedowns or to achieve a decisive win by a pin, which involves holding the opponent's shoulders firmly to the mat. In the Olympic Games, there are two primary styles: Freestyle, which permits attacks to the entire body, and Greco-Roman, which restricts holds to the upper body. The sport requires an immense combination of strength, speed, agility, and technical skill, making it a challenging test of athleticism. Victory is typically determined by the total number of points scored across the match's two periods or by successfully pinning the opponent.
history_description: Wrestling is one of humanity's oldest competitive sports, with evidence from ancient civilizations. It was a central event in the Ancient Olympic Games starting in 708 BC. The modern Greco-Roman style was codified in 19th-century France. The sport remains one of the few to have appeared at nearly every modern Olympic Games.
equipment: Mat, Singlet (uniform), Headgear (optional for some styles/competitors).
